metadata.title: Multivariate Probability Theory: All About Those Random Variables | by Shuai Guo | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Multivariate Probability Theory: All About Those Random Variables
metadata.description: In this post, we will review some of the most useful probability concepts applied to multiple random variables. In particular, I will show you how those concepts are logically connected. An Intuition…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Zero-Math Introduction to Markov Chain Monte Carlo Methods
Bayesian inference problem, MCMC, and variational inference

all_paragraphs: In this post, we will review some of the most useful probability concepts applied to multiple random variables. In particular, I will show you how those concepts are logically connected.

An Intuition for each concept is built first before discussing the math. That’s why I’ve created many illustrations to facilitate visually explaining abstract concepts. I’ve also included links for related topics this post didn’t cover. A linkable table of content is provided below, in case you want to jump into specific topics directly. I hope those efforts could offer you a better reading experience.
If you want to refresh your knowledge on concepts like random variable, probability density function, expectation, or variance, feel free to check out my previous post:

· 1. Random vector· 2. Scatter plot· 3. Joint probability density function ∘ 3.1 Bivariate joint PDF ∘ 3.2 Multivariate joint PDF· 4. Marginal distribution ∘ 4.1 Intuition ∘ 4.2 Multivariate marginal distribution· 5. Conditional distribution ∘ 5.1 Intuition ∘ 5.2 Conditional probability ∘ 5.3 Theoretical treatment ∘ 5.4 Properties ∘ 5.5 Multivariate conditional distributions· 6. Bayes’ rule ∘ 6.1 Formula ∘ 6.2 Bayesian statistics — Intuition ∘ 6.3 Bayesian statistics — Computation· 7. Independence ∘ 7.1 Definition ∘ 7.2 Visualization ∘ 7.3 Conditional independence ∘ 7.4 Multivariate cases· 8. Expectation and variance ∘ 8.1 Expectation ∘ 8.2 Variance· 9. Covariance ∘ 9.1 Definition and intuition ∘ 9.2 Computation ∘ 9.3 Properties ∘ 9.4 Covariance of independent variables ∘ 9.5 Correlation coefficients ∘ 9.6 Covariance matrix· Summary· Reference· About the Author
A random vector is a list of random variables. For example, given two random variables X₁ and X₂, then X =[X₁, X₂] constitutes a random vector.

If we toss a coin twice, we could use X₁ and X₂ to represent the first and second toss outcomes, respectively. The corresponding random vector X would take values of [head, head], [head, tail], [tail, tail], or [tail, head].

If we measure the height and the weight of an adult male, we could use X₁ and X₂ to represent the height and weight value, respectively. Then the values of the corresponding random vector X could be various combinations of height and weight value.

Practical machine learning models seldomly rely on a single feature to make predictions. Instead, multiple features are usually taken into account, and their relationship and interactions are mined to yield meaningful insights. As a result, we need the concept of the random vector and the supporting probability theories to characterize its statistical properties.

In the following, we will be mainly talking about bivariate cases, where we have two random variables. The extension of the probability concepts to multivariate cases is summarized at the end of individual sections.
Given a dataset of two random variables X₁ and X₂, the easiest way to visualize their relationship is by drawing a scatter plot.

The figure below shows the scatter plot of the sepal length and width of the iris dataset. This plot uses dots to represent the data points, where the horizontal and vertical position of each dot indicate the values for sepal length and sepal width, respectively.

A scatter plot is great for identifying the correlation pattern between two numeric variables. As can be spotted in the above figure, the sepal length and the width are positively correlated, i.e., if sepal length is increased, we would have a high chance to observe increased sepal width too. Different correlation patterns displayed in scatter plots are discussed in the latter part of this post.

A joint probability density function, or a joint PDF, in short, is used to characterize the joint probability distribution of multiple random variables. In this section, we will start by discussing the joint PDF concerning only two random variables. Later on, we will generalize the discussion to multiple random variables.

For two random variables X₁ and X₂, we are usually interested in the probability of observing their values fall within a specific region of the parameter space. This can be seen as a joint event (A & B), as event A is X₁ falls within R₁, and event B is X₂ falls within R₂. Recall that a PDF for a single random variable is sufficient to measure the probability of a single event (event A or B). To characterize the probability of a joint event (event A & B happen simultaneously), however, we would need a joint PDF f(x₁, x₂) instead.

Now, if we define event A as “X₁ observed in [x₁, x₁+dx₁]” and event B as “X₂ observed in [x₂, x₂+dx₂],” then the probability of the joint event A & B, i.e., the probability for a point to be observed within the red square (see figure below), is given by the joint PDF times the area of the square, f(x₁, x₂)dx₁dx₂:
To summarize we’ve discussed regarding the joint PDF, let’s decompose its name:
Equipped with the concept of a joint PDF, we can now express the joint probability that X₁ falls in [a₁, b₁] and X₂ falls in [a₂, b₂] as a double integral:

If we integrate f(x₁, x₂) over the entire parameter space S of x₁ and x₂, the result would be 1. This is expected as the probability for X₁ and X₂ to take values within their respect possible ranges has to be one, i.e., it’s bound to happen.
The above-discussed joint PDF concept can also be extended to multivariate cases, where n random variables X₁,…, Xₙ are considered.

A multivariate joint PDF f(x₁,…, xₙ) is defined to characterize the probability of a joint event, where each of the n random variables falls in a specific range. Consequently, we can express the probability P(a₁ ≤ X₁ ≤ b₁,…, aₙ ≤ Xₙ ≤ bₙ) as:
Same as the bivariate joint PDF, if we integrate f(x₁,…, xₙ) over its entire parameter space S, the result would be 1.

Given the joint PDF of multiple random variables, what can we say about each variable's probability distribution individually? This question often arises in practice when we have direct access to a joint PDF, but we are only interested in the probability distribution of several important variables.
The probability distribution of a subset of the random variables is called the marginal distribution. Deriving this probability distribution is known as marginalization.

Suppose we have a scatter plot of X₁ and X₂. If we are only interested in estimating the marginal distribution of X₂, f(x₂), the easiest way would be to simply project each dot onto the y-axis and plot the corresponding histogram. After normalizing the obtained histogram, which involves scaling the histogram such that the area sum of the bins is one, we obtain f(x₂). This practice could work since we are only interested in the distribution of X₂ regardless of how X₁ is distributed. Therefore, we can simply ignore the X₁ column in the dataset and directly plot a histogram based on the X₂ column, which leads to the marginal distribution of X₂.

Let’s take another look at what we’ve just discussed. The marginal distribution of X₂ measures the probability that X₂ falls in an infinitesimal interval [x₂, x₂+dx₂], which, in a scatter plot (shown below, Fig. 6(b)), is the same as the probability for an (x₁, x₂) point falls within the band.

If we regard the band as consisting of squares of area dx₁dx₂, each labeled by an index (1, 2,…), then we can compute the target probability by summing the probabilities corresponding to the individual squares:
In the limit of infinitesimal dx₁, the sum becomes an integral:
Obviously, we could do the same to derive the marginal distribution of x₁, f(x₁):
The above two equations have shown us how to derive a marginal distribution from its associated joint PDF.
The above-discussed marginal distribution concept can also be extended to multivariate cases, where n random variables X₁,…, Xₙ are considered.
The marginal distribution of X₁, for example, is now expressed as
Also, we can now define joint marginal distributions such as f(x₁, x₂), where

For two random variables X₁ and X₂, the marginal distribution of X₁ informs us about the behavior of X₁ regardless of how X₂ is distributed. However, on some occasions, we may have already observed X₂ value, and we want to find out whether our knowledge of X₂ will influence how we think X₁ is distributed.

In the language of probability, we are actually looking for the distribution of X₁, conditioned on X₂ takes a specific value. This type of distribution is known as the conditional distribution. Conditional distribution constitutes a key concept in statistical inference, where a major goal is to deduce the parameter distribution conditioned on the observed data.

Given a scatter plot of X₁ and X₂, we can easily estimate the conditional distribution of X₂ given X₁ equals a, for example. Mathematically, we express this conditional distribution function as f(x₂|x₁=a), where the variable on the left side of “|” denotes the variable that is described by the distribution function, while the expression on the right side of “|” represents the applied condition.

We can estimate f(x₂|x₁=a) in the following way: Step 1: we only focus on those data points conforming to the applied condition, i.e., x₁=a. Those eligible points now constitute the new sample space. In practice, we usually settle for a thin band [a, a+ε] for X₁ (as illustrated below), as finding a point with its X₁ value being exactly a is not always possible.Step 2: we project those data points bounded by the thin band (marked in red below) onto the X₂ axis. By plotting the histogram and performing the normalization procedure on the histogram, we obtain f(x₂|x₁=a).

If we step back and review what we just did from a more theoretical point of view, we would notice that to derive the conditional distribution of X₂ given X₁ equals a, we are in fact looking for a probability density function f(x₂|x₁=a), which, according to the definition of a PDF, when multiplying dx₂, yields the following probability:
To get f(x₂|x₁=a), we need to know how to compute the probability on the right-hand side of the equation. To that end, we need to recall the concept of conditional probability.

The probability of an event B occurring given some event A has occurred is known as a conditional probability, denoted by P(B|A). By applying this definition to the above equation, we would see that event A corresponds to X₁ falling within [a, a+ε], and event B corresponds to X₂ falling within [x₂, x₂+dx₂].

As illustrated in the figure below, we have a sample space S and two subspaces A and B, representing events A and B, respectively. Calculating P(B|A) amounts to calculating the number of elements contained in the intersection of subspace A and B, relative to the number of elements contained in the whole subspace A:
If we divide both the numerator and denominator by n(S), i.e., the number of elements in the entire sample space S, we obtain:
This gives us the formula to calculate the conditional probability.
Once we understand how to calculate the required conditional probability, we can derive the target conditional PDF f(x₂|x₁=a):
Eliminating dx₂ on both sides, we obtain the formula for calculating the conditional PDF:
By generalizing a to be any value that X₁ could take, we obtain the expression of the conditional PDF for X₂ given X₁ as:
Similarly, we could express the conditional PDF for X₁ given X₂ as:
First of all, the conditional PDF f(x₂|x₁) is a probability density function of x₂ (similarly, f(x₁|x₂) is a PDF of x₁). This means:
To see this more clearly, we have
Notice that the integral on the right-hand side of the equation is actually the definition of the marginal distribution of X₁:
Therefore, we can prove that the integral of f(x₂|x₁) with respect to x₂ equals one, i.e., f(x₂|x₁) is indeed a PDF.
Consequently, we can express conditional probabilities like P(a ≤ X₂ ≤ b|X₁=x₁) as:

Secondly, the conditional PDF f(x₂|x₁) is, in general, a function of x₁, meaning that the shape of f(x₂|x₁) will be different when X₁ takes different values. However, one notable exception is when X₁ and X₂ are statistically independent. We will dive deeper into this topic in the latter part of this post.
Finally, the conditional distribution gives us another way to express the marginal distribution. Notice that we can write the joint PDF as:
If we integrate both sides with respect to X₁, then
Since the left-hand side term gives us the marginal distribution of X₂, we have the following:
This formula is known as the law of total probability.
We can extend our discussion of bivariate conditional PDF to multivariate situations. For example, the conditional distribution of X₁ given that X₂=x₂, X₃=x₃,…, Xₙ=xₙ is written as:
where the numerator is the joint PDF of X₁,…, Xₙ, and the denominator is the joint marginal distribution of X₂,…, Xₙ.
Also, we can write the joint conditional distribution of X₁ and X₂ given that X₃=x₃,…, Xₙ=xₙ as:
where the numerator is the joint PDF of X₁,…, Xₙ, and the denominator is the joint marginal distribution of X₃,…, Xₙ.
A common application of conditional distribution is to factorize the joint PDF. For example, we can factorize f(x₁, x₂, x₃) in the following form:
This could be useful in practice as f(x₁, x₂, x₃) may be hard to compute directly, but its associated conditional distributions like f(x₁|x₂, x₃) and f(x₂|x₃) are relatively easy to calculate.
Now we can introduce one of the most important rules in probability theory, the foundation of Bayesian inference — Bayes’ rule.

As we already discussed in the previous section, we can write the joint PDF as a multiplication of a conditional PDF and a marginal PDF. For two random variables X₁ and X₂, that means we have the following two expressions, which are both valid:
As a result, we obtain the following relationship between f(x₂|x₁) and f(x₁|x₂):
The above formula is the famous Bayes’ rule.

If we flip a coin 10 times and we observed 7 heads and 3 tails, how confident can we say that this coin is fair? Given it’s cloudy in the morning, what’s the probability of raining in the afternoon? Given a dataset of input-output pairs, what’re the best parameters to constitute a line to fit the data? How certain are we if these fitted parameters are the right ones? All those questions can be addressed by Bayesian statistics.
Bayesian statistics offers a way to perform statistical inference, i.e., uncovering the underlying probabilistic model from the observed data.

Under a Bayesian setting, inference usually begins with assumptions regarding the underlying probabilistic model. We may know the model takes some possible forms, and the associated model parameters are bounded by some ranges. Those assumptions constitute our prior knowledge. Next, we start to collect data samples. We hope the observed data could tell us more about the model that generates the data. Lastly, we apply Bayes’ rule to extract insights from the observed data and update our prior knowledge to arrive at a posterior estimation.

Bayesian statistical inference can be seen as a process of reallocation of credibility across possibilities: we have our suspicion of possible scenarios, where each possible scenario is assigned with a probability. Later on, based on the observed data, we can re-assign the probability for each scenario, where scenarios that are aligned to the data pattern get higher probabilities and scenarios that are differed from the data pattern get lower probabilities.

Bayesian statistics is elegant as it describes this abstract knowledge update process in a quantifiable manner. To see that better, let’s take a closer look at each component in the Bayes’ formula. But first, instead of using generic x₁ and x₂, let’s give Bayes’ rule some context and rewrite the formula:
Here, θ represents the parameter of the underlying probabilistic model that we are trying to estimate, and D denotes the observed data.
A breakdown of the Bayes’ formula is given below, followed by a description of each term.

f(θ) → the prior distribution of θ. This term encodes our beliefs about the true parameter value before seeing any data. It is our initial hypothesis;f(D|θ) → the likelihood function. This term calculates the likelihood of observing the data conditioned on specific θ values from the initial hypothesis;f(θ|D) → the posterior distribution of θ. This term is what we are trying to estimate, i.e., given the data, our up-to-date beliefs about θ.f(D) → the evidence. This term is the overall probability of observing the data, calculated as the average of the likelihood function, f(D|θ), across all values of θ, weighted by the prior probability of θ, f(θ):
As a result, this term also goes with another name: marginal likelihood.

The evidence f(D) is independent of θ, as θ has already been integrated out. On many occasions, f(D) is simply a normalizing constant to ensure that f(θ|D) is a proper probability density function. As a result, we usually skip calculating f(D) when deriving f(θ|D). Instead, we settle for:
We can normalize f(θ|D) to a proper PDF afterward.

On other occasions, we may have several different models that can potentially generate the observed data. Now, our primary interest would be to identify the most probable model, as opposed to finding the most probable parameter under a given model. There, f(D) should become f(D|M), i.e, the probability of observing the data will be conditioned on the specific model. Bayesian model selection technique use f(D|M) to determine the relative probability that the data is generated by the model M.

In practice, it is common that the likelihood function f(D|θ) and the prior f(θ) are complicated enough to prevent an analytical solution of the posterior f(θ|D). Against this background, researchers have developed methods like Laplace’s approximation, Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), and variational Bayes (VB) to facilitate Bayesian calculations.

To read more about MCMC, check out Ben Shaver’s “Zero-Math Introduction to Markov Chain Monte Carlo Methods.” For understanding VB, see Joseph Rocca’s “Bayesian inference problem, MCMC, and variational inference.”
When two random variables X₁ and X₂ are not related in any way, we say X₁ and X₂ are statistically independent.
If X₁ and X₂ are independent random variables, we would have:

This is expected since the outcome of X₂ has no influence on the outcome of X₁ and vice versa. Therefore, the conditional distribution f(x₂|x₁) would be the same for all x₁, and f(x₁|x₂) would be the same for all x₂. This implies that knowing one of the variables does not help us understand the other better.
Therefore, for independent random variables, we could factorize the joint PDF as a series of products of the PDFs of individual variables.
In practice, we can visually assess whether X₁ and X₂ are independent via their scatter plot.

The figure below shows the situation when X₁ and X₂ are dependent. As highlighted by the black dashed line, the pattern between X₁ and X₂ are clear: as X₁ increases or decreases, X₂ tends to do the same. This dependence is further demonstrated by plotting the conditional PDFs f(x₂|x₁=a) and f(x₂|x₁=b). Obviously, those two conditional PDFs are different, meaning that X₂ behaves differently when conditioned on different X₁ values. This is another way of saying X₁ and X₂ are dependent.

Here is how the scatter plot would look like when X₁ and X₂ are independent. There is no obvious relationship between X₁ and X₂: knowing X₁’s value won’t tell us where X₂ would locate. By plotting the f(x₂|x₁=a) and f(x₂|x₁=b), we can see that those two conditional PDFs almost identical (the small discrepancy is caused by the PDF estimation process), meaning that how X₁ behaves has no impact on how X₂ is distributed.

Conditional independence refers to the situation that X₁ and X₂ are independent given X₃. In other words, the knowledge of X₃ will make two could-be dependent random variables X₁ and X₂ independent. Mathematically, conditional independence is written as follows:
To gain some intuition of this concept, let’s look at a simple example:

A box contains two coins: a regular coin, and a fake two-tailed coin. I choose a coin at random and toss it twice. Now, consider:Event A: First coin toss shows a tail;Event B: Second coin toss shows a tail;Event C: The regular coin has been selected.

Events A and B are not independent since the occurrence of event A will affect the occurrence probability of event B, i.e., P(B|A) ≠ P(B). This is intuitively understandable: if we know event A has occurred, it is more likely that we’ve selected the two-tailed coin, which in turn increases the probability that event B occurs. However, if we have the knowledge of event C, then events A and B become independent as our thought experiment reduces to tossing a regular coin twice and examining their results. Events A and B become independent in light of event C. That’s the basic meaning of conditional independence.

Conditional independence is useful as it usually simplifies the factorization of the joint PDF. Recall the following formula we first encountered in Section “5.5 Multivariate conditional distributions”:

If our problem at hand implies that X₁ and X₂ are conditionally independent given X₃, we can write f(x₁|x₂, x₃) as f(x₁|x₃). This is true since once we know the value of X₃, which value X₂ takes won’t affect how X₁ is distributed. Therefore, we can simplify the joint PDF as:

This type of simplification is essential in the Bayesian networks, which is a probabilistic model that uses graphics to model conditional dependence. To read more about Bayesian networks, see Devin Soni’s “Introduction to Bayesian Networks.”
The concept of independence can be easily generalized to multiple random variables: given random variables X₁,…, Xₙ, they are said to be statistically independent if and only if
Conditional independence can also be applied to multiple random variables. For example, we may have X₁ and X₂ are independent given X₃ and X₄, which can be expressed as:

Conditional dependencies soon get complex when multiple random variables are involved. It is common to use a graphical model such as Bayesian networks to summarize those dependencies compactly in these circumstances.
Same as the univariate case, we also use expectation and variance to describe the distribution of multiple random variables.

For a single random variable X, the expectation indicates the average value X would take. When we have more than one variable, the expectation becomes a vector, which consists of the expectation values of each variable. For example, for a random vector X =[X₁, X₂], its expectation E(X) = [E(X₁), E(X₂)].
Calculating E(X₁) of a joint distribution of X₁ and X₂ follows the definition of the expectation:
Here, f(x₁) is the marginal distribution of X₁. Recall the definition of the marginal distribution:
Substituting the above equation into the expression of E(X₁), we have:
Similar, we have the following expression for E(X₂):

For a single random variable X, variance var(X) measures the amount of its variability around its expectation E[X]. For multiple random variables, the variance becomes a vector, consisting of the variance values of each variable. For example, for a random vector X =[X₁, X₂], its variance var(X) = [var(X₁), var(X₂)].
Calculating var(X₁) of a joint distribution of X₁ and X₂ follows the definition of the variance:
Like calculating expectation values, we use the marginal distribution of X₁, f(x₁), in the above integral.
By Substituting the expression of f(x₁) into the above equation, we have:
Similar, we have the following expression for var(X₂):
For the multivariate case, we need to introduce an extra concept of covariance to measure the dependency between pairs of random variables.

Similar to the concept of variance, which measures the variation of a single variable, covariance measures how two variables vary together. For random variables X₁ and X₂, their covariance is defined as:

If large values of X₁ often result in large values of X₂ (figure below, left), the product (X₁-E[X₁])(X₂-E[X₂]) will tend to be positive. On the other hand, if large values of X₁ often lead to small values of X₂ (figure below, right), the product (X₁-E[X₁])(X₂-E[X₂]) will tend to be negative. Therefore, the sign of the covariance indicates whether two random variables are positively correlated or negatively correlated.
In practice, it can be simpler to compute covariance in the following way:
To derive the above equation, we follow:
The covariance operator has the following properties. All of them can be proven directly from the definition of covariance.
When random variables X₁ and X₂ are statistically independent, their covariance is zero.
Let’s see how to prove this statement. For independent random variables, we can factorize their joint PDF f(x₁, x₂) = f(x₁)f(x₂). Therefore:

One downside of using covariance is that its magnitude does not indicate anything regarding the strength of the relationship between X₁ and X₂, simply because covariance Cov(X₁, X₂) is not scale-free.
To address this issue, we need to introduce the correlation coefficient:

The correlation coefficient may go with other names, such as Pearson’s correlation coefficient, bivariate correlation, etc. It can be seen as a standardized form of covariance and measures how strong X₁ and X₂ are linearly correlated.

The correlation coefficient’s value is bounded by +1 and −1. Scatter plots with different correlation strengths are shown below. A positive ρ value indicates the two random variables are positively correlated, and a negative ρ value says the opposite. When ρ reaches +/-1, this means there is a strictly linear relationship between two variables.

However, mind that among all sorts of relationships, correlation/covariance only measures the linear association. This means that a zero correlation does not necessarily imply two variables are independent. Those two variables can still be associated in some non-linear ways. However, if those two variables are truly independent, their correlation/covariance will be zero.
When working with multiple random variables, we need a covariance matrix to summarize the covariances of all pairs of variables succinctly.

For n random variables X₁,…, Xₙ, their associated covariance matrix is demonstrated below. It is a n-by-n square matrix, whose (i, j)th entry is the covariance between Xᵢ and Xⱼ, i.e., Kᵢⱼ = Cov(Xᵢ, Xⱼ).

A covariance matrix is a symmetry matrix, since Cov(Xᵢ, Xⱼ) = Cov(Xⱼ, Xᵢ), therefore Kᵢⱼ = Kⱼᵢ. In addition, the diagonal terms of a covariance matrix are the variance of individual random variables, i.e., Kᵢᵢ = Cov(Xᵢ, Xᵢ) = var(Xᵢ).

This post has covered many practical probability theories applied to multiple random variables: random vector, joint probability density function, marginal and conditional distributions, Bayes’ rule and fundamental Bayesian statistics, independence, expectation, variance, and covariance/correlation. Also, we touched upon scatter plots, which are useful for visualizing the data distribution and enabling intuitive understandings of various multivariate probability theories.
If you want to see the similarities and differences between univariate and multivariate probability theories, please check out my previous post for further information:
[1] Walpole, Probability & Statistics for Engineers & Scientists, Pearson, 2016.[2] Glen Cowan, statistical data analysis, Oxford University Press, 1997.

I’m a Ph.D. researcher working on uncertainty quantification and reliability analysis for aerospace applications. Statistics and data science form the core of my daily work. I love sharing what I’ve learned in the fascinating world of statistics. Check my previous posts to find out more and connect with me on Medium and Linkedin.
Data scientist, aerospace engineer, specialized in statistical modeling and uncertainty analysis for reliable system design.
